dialogues.text: Prove it. Prove to me you’re not a little bitch. El Sol fakes a movement -- Smiley flinches -- he shakes h head in disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: SMILEY
dialogues.text: Send me. Send me to find... to kill El Casper. El Sol looks at Smiley, a tear drips down his face. El Sol pulls out a rusted .38 Special and points it in Smiley’s face. Smiley flinches. Sol flips the gun around and gives it to Smiley.

dialogues.speaker: EL SOL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go then. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Smiley... until El Casper is dead, you can’t step one foot in La Confeti. Smiley avoids the stare of the men, then turns and heads of the house. Annoyed and impatient, Sol turns his attent to the group.

dialogues.speaker: EL SOL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Call the L.A. ranfleros. Everyone must know, everyone’s got to be on the look out for El Casper. He will have no where to hide... The hatred in El Sol’s face is palpable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can see all the immigrants, even the ones far in the front, holding onto the side of the cars. Horacio slaps h face to stay awake. Sayra sleeps in between them. Orlando begins to drift off into sleep, but Horacio slaps him. Orlando looks at Horacio surprised. Sayra sits up. She motions for Orlando to lay down. They switch places and he lies down between her and Horacio. Horacio grabs her hand. His eyes are heavy with exhaustio

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Sleep, I’1l hold on to both of you.  62 63 58. He shakes his head no, silently mouthing that he’s okay. Branches swoosh by, whipping the faces of immigrants sitt too high.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER SIDE OF BOXCAR
dialogues.text: Willy struggles to stay awake. He unbuckles his belt, wra it through a ring on the wagon top and around his waist again. Below him, between the train cars, a group of immigrants to keep themselves awake, their voices are rough, but the sing with conviction. His eyes close for a moment, then he shakes awake again. feels something in his pocket, realizing he still has the camera, he pulls it out. Turns it on. The glow of the screen illuminates his face. He looks at the IMAGES of Martha Marlene. His eyes tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s quiet, other than the sound of the creaking train ca and the muffled hammering of iron wheels. The dawn light reveals the overwhelming fatigue on everyo face, some of whom haven’t slept in four days. The train cruises through the largest town they’ve seen y A sign reads ISLAS next to the train tracks. The creaking train rolls past stores and markets opening their doors t the new day. Pedestrians on the streets watch the passing train, half amused, half asleep, while the Immigrants watch the passi town hypnotized with fatigue. Willy, LOLLIPOP in mouth, starts to climb down the stairs but notices Sayra is watching him. She shakes her head, a if to say, “don’t go.” He drops down between the cars anyway, unzips his pants a urinates. The idea of jumping off and disappearing into t town dissipates as soon as he begins seeing “M” “S" graff along the tracks, just beyond the observing stares of the CITIZENS of the town. The train is the only home he has n His phone beeps again. He pulls it out. It’s dead. He drops it beneath the train and climbs back up. Sayra and make prolonged eye contact, she smiles to herself.  64 65 59. EXT. TIERRA BLANCA —- DAY 64

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: SUPER: U.S. Border, 1100 NORTH The train pulls into a similarly ragged and industrial station as the one in Tapachula. Willy notices the large “Devil’s Hand” of the Mara Salvatrucha spray painted on the side of a concrete build Willy scans the horizon, looking for other signs of his former “brothers.” Every LONE FIGURE looks like a danger him. Along the tracks he spots a MAN scanning the immigrants o the trains. Willy’s defenses immediately go on alert. The make eye-contact, the man walks towards the train, then disappears behind a wagon. The train slows to a crawl as the 300 Immigrants pile off train. Some, including Orlando, kneel to the ground and pray. Willy stays atop the train, glancing between Sayra and a GROUP OF MEN he thinks could be Mareros melting into the crowd. Just as he’s about to lose sight of Sayra she moti for him to follow her. He jumps down, tucking his machete under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiley throws rocks into the trash filled river below. Th same THREE KIDS from the colonia sit and listen to him.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: You're going to hurt him? Smiley nods. The kids mimic his side armed throwing style

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: You're not going to kill him though, are you? Smiley nods.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: But it’s Casper.  66 60. Smiley throws another rock hard, then another, with each throw he tries to convince himself he’s man enough.

dialogues.speaker: SMILEY
dialogues.text: It’s the responsibility of a true Marero to avenge the death of another. Be it Casper or whoever. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I’m gonna do it... I gotta do it.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: How? You gotta gun? Smiley pulls out the rusted .38 -- the kids are both awed afraid. Smiley smiles at its (and transversely, his own) power, tucking the pistol away again into his pants.

dialogues.speaker: SMILEY
dialogues.text: La Mara. Down the tracks in La Bombilla, the train’s WHISTLE BLOWS Smiley nods goodbye to the kids then heads off down the tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy follows Sayra and her family and about 20 immigrant towards a rest house -- a small concrete home with a pati situated off the tracks. Inside, Immigrants gather to shower, change clothes, and rest in the shade. He eyes everyone carefully, evaluating -- anyone could be look out for the Maras, or any other gang that could want kill him. Horacio grabs Sayra, motioning towards Willy.

dialogues.speaker: HORACIO
dialogues.text: He’s following us. Sayra knows why. Orlando watches, unsure what to say.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: We could help him.

dialogues.speaker: HORACIO
dialogues.text: Absolutely not. You’re to keep away from him.  67

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA HORACIO
dialogues.text: Are you ordering me? He’s a murderer- Yes, yes I’m ordering you.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: He’s in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: HORACIO
dialogues.text: I don’t care about him. I care about us. Sayra is disgusted with Horacio, she looks to Orlando for support but he says nothing. Horacio, acutely annoyed, pu out the XEROX MAP from his pocket. HORACIO (CONT’D) Look. He points to TIERRA BLANCA, still only 1/3 of the way to US BORDER. Sayra is subtly surprised.

dialogues.speaker: HORACIO
dialogues.text: We're here. We've got a long way to go, Sayra. We have to stay sharp, stick together. We can’t let anyone ruin this, for us, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has set but the sky is still light. Thirty** immigrants linger on the patio. Some eat, some sleep, som re-apply make-up, some talk on a pay phone with home. Horacio is in line for the phone while Orlando talks with SEVERAL other immigrants about their economic predicament back home (45 lempiras a day speech). Sayra, fresh from a shower, sits in front of a GIRL who braids her hair, the girl compliments Sayra’s skin. She tries to make herself look pretty again. In a darkened corner of the patio, Willy sits by himself watching the others. No one approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired and bored immigrants lie about. Sayra squats next t Willy.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: You going to wash up?  62. Willy shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: It feels nice.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Later, maybe. When there are less people.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Then what’1ll you do?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Dunno.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: You going to stay here for the night? Willy shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: If I find any food, I’1l bring you some. Willy is unsure how to take her kindness. Sayra smiles, t leaves him to his thoughts. LOCALS sit in their patios eating food. The immigrants stare at them enviously, smacking their dry mouths. Atop one of the abandoned train cars, THREE IMMIGRANTS li cigarettes, then one of them bellows out in a joking tone

dialogues.speaker: IMMIGRANT HOST
dialogues.text: Thank you and welcome to the show! I know some of you have come from as far away as San Pedro Sula to see this, you won’t be disappointed! First up on our line up, Eugenio will sing a love ballad to his third and ugliest wife... For a moment, the immigrants laugh, able to forget the hu pangs and boredom. Both Willy and Sayra smile. He looks around at the other smiling faces, one of them, a glue sniffer with no teeth smiles while looking at him hard, h makes the sign of a Barrio 18, but Willy doesn’t really flinch, he knows he’s just a glue sniffer.  68 69

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy walks past Horacio on the way to the showers. grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: HORACIO
dialogues.text: What’s your name son?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: (pulling his arm from Horacio’s grasp) Willy.

dialogues.speaker: HORACIO
dialogues.text: Willy... my name is Horacio. That girl over there, she’s my daughter, Sayra, and he over there is my little brother, Orlando. They’re my family and they mean more to me than anything else. For what you did on the train, maybe I owe you something. If it’s money you want, I'll give you some as soon as my wire comes in, other than that, I don’t know you, I don’t trust you, and I don’t want you coming anywhere near my family. Do you understand me? Willy nods, he knows Horacio’s type. Stubborn and impenetrable. He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy and Sayra help prepare a meal for the Sefiora house, a kind faced middle aged woman. He notices contrails of a passenger-jet over head. He stares enough that she notices and squints to see what he’ at.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Ever been on one? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Me neither. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Texas I saw the factory where they make them- 63. 68 Horacio 69 of the the at it long s looking  64.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: -You’ve been to Texas?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I've been to little of everywhere. This factory had this huge globe, like a giant ball, all lit up and bright. I wanted to climb it.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: I‘’1l look for it, when I get there.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: If you get there.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: I will. I know I will. Back home, my friend Clarissa made me see this crazy neighbor, Dofia Eleanor, you know, like witchcraft? She smoked this puro, then told me with her freaky voice that I'd make it to the U.S. but not in God’s hand, perhaps in the Devils.’

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: My girl saw a woman like that once.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: (playing it nonchalant) You have a girl? Martha Marlen’s death hits Willy again. Willy focuses on work again.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: No. The conversation falls into silence. Sayra looks at Willy who seems like his mind is elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: You should come with us. We’re going to New Jersey. Willy doesn’t even look at her.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I don’t think your father would be cool with that.  65.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter, he’s my father only in blood.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: And your mom?

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Hurricane Mitch. Just sort of... swept her away. Almost swept us both away, but it didn’t, I guess. Willy listens quietly.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: It was a long time ago. I don’t really remember her. I remember him even less. I was a baby when he left for the North. She motions to Horacio.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: New Jersey, huh?

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Better to be disguised with immigrants, no? If they come for you. Willy thinks about his predicament. The weight of it is heavy.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: They will come for you. Won't they?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Maybe. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If not now... one day. They’ve got a good memory.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Aren’t you afraid?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Of death? No. I’ve always lived for the day. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only hard part is not knowing where it’1ll come from.  70 66.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Must be hard for the people who love you... if you think like that. Willy nods.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter to me if you come, either way we go. So, there you have it. Sayra turns and walks away, quietly embarrassed. Horacio watches, feeling his continued loss of control over his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiley slips a phone card into a pay booth. He pulls out scrap of paper with a number written on it. The first tim he dials he messes up. He tries again.

dialogues.speaker: SMILEY
dialogues.text: Abue? It’s Benny... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been gone, you didn’t know? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Working. Abuela. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I have a job. It’s a good job, delivering vegetables to Veracruz. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m not alone... I’m with Casper. I’ve got to go... I’ll be home... it might be some time. Smiley notices SEVEN MEN staring at him from under a lamp post. Unsure about himself, he makes the “m-s” sign with hands. They acknowledge him with the same sign. Smiley calls out meekly...

dialogues.speaker: SMILEY
dialogues.text: Quien lleva la palabra? A younger looking man with a thick keloid scar from his c down his neck steps forward...

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: Yo mero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 67. One of the Mareros, EL PAJARO, a muscular man with a croo Mayan nose and deep set eyes looks Smiley up and down...

dialogues.speaker: SMILEY
dialogues.text: I’m El Smiley from La Confeti? El Scarface looks him over, suspiciously, his hand drifts over his PISTOL stuck in his pants.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: Estas entintado? Smiley shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: Quien lleva la palabra en tu clica ahora?

dialogues.speaker: SMILEY
dialogues.text: El Sol. El Scarface relaxes slightly, greeting Smiley with a handshake and embracing like tough guys.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: We heard what happened. Are you hungry or thirsty? Smiley can only shake his head no. Two cars pull up, a red 1987 NISSAN SENTRA and a brown 19 TOYOTA CARROLA. The cars look like shit and sound like go carts, but the stereo systems are top notch. EXT. EL LIL’ MAGO’S PATIO - DAY A71 El Sol, alone with Lil Mago’s kid, and his own, watches o the two toddlers. He has a bitter sweet smile on his face His cell phone rings, he doesn’t look excited to pick up phone.

dialogues.speaker: EL SOL
dialogues.text: Jomi? Cut back and forth from:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: El Scarface sits on the hood of his car, phone to his ear In the back ground, inside the rest stop, Smiley and othe Mareros question immigrants.  72 68.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: Sup’ jomi? We've got one of yours here.

dialogues.speaker: EL SOL
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: So what am I supposed to do with him?

dialogues.speaker: EL SOL
dialogues.text: Use him. However you want.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: Will you be sending more?

dialogues.speaker: EL SOL
dialogues.text: Thing is... I can’t really do that right now.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: You can’t do that now?

dialogues.speaker: EL SOL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: EL SOL
dialogues.text: The word is out, jomi. He won’t get away, we got problems down here at the moment, you know? But the word is out. El Casper ain't going no where.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: No. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barrio won’t let him.

dialogues.speaker: EL SOL
dialogues.text: Va. 1'’11 check in with you later. El Sol hangs up the phone. His face reveals his fatigue w this routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: El Scarface is not happy about the call. He looks at Smil who talks to the SENORA...  69.

dialogues.speaker: SMILEY
dialogues.text: You sure you haven’t seen him? He’s got a tear drop here.

dialogues.speaker: REST STOP OWNER
dialogues.text: No corazon, I haven’t seen anyone with a tattoo in the last few days until you guys. El Scarface waves Smiley over, he knows he’s wasting time with the Sefiora. El Pajaro and the other Mareros are bor with the search. A GLUE SNIFFING MAN steps forward. He has a bag of glue hanging in his hands and yellow crust around his nostrils

dialogues.speaker: GLUE SNIFFER
dialogues.text: Give me 100 pesos and I’11 tell you where to look. El Scarface joins them, smoking a cigarette while summing the man.

dialogues.speaker: EL PAJARO
dialogues.text: We checked the yards and shelters.

dialogues.speaker: GLUE SNIFFER
dialogues.text: Not there. 100 pesos. El Pajaro ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: EL PAJARO
dialogues.text: Would he have stayed on the train? Maybe he got off before.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: What about the farms?

dialogues.speaker: GLUE SNIFFER
dialogues.text: Ah, ah, ah.

dialogues.speaker: EL PAJARO
dialogues.text: We talked to the bosses, the workers are all chapines. El Scarface pulls out 100 pesos, dropping it on the groun before the man. With great effort, he picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: GLUE SNIFFER
dialogues.text: I saw the one you’re looking for. A tear drop here. (pointing to his eye) He’s gone. With immigrants.  73 70. He points North, laughing. Smiley and El Pajaro look at E Scarface for direction, he motions to the car. EL SCARFACE (CONT’D) Smiley. El Pajaro and the others get back in their cars EL SCARFACE (CONT’D) El Casper’s one of your padrinos? Smiley nods.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: You ever shot a man, Smiley?

dialogues.speaker: SMILEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Scarface doesn’t believe it, but he humours the boy. EL SCARFACE (CONT’D) If you see him, shoot him quick. No point in thinking about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy, Sayra and family sit atop another train car. The train accelerates through the farmlands towards a foggy mountain range looming across the Northern skyline. Everyone sits quietly, lost in their thoughts. Their head rock back and forth with the movement of the train. On the horizon above the train, along a ridge of low lyin mountains, a gigantic STATUE OF JESUS stands like Lady Liberty, it’s arms spread out to welcome them. Orlando looks at the Jesus and crosses himself, whisperin inaudible prayer over the photograph of Ceci. Sayra prays well while Horacio stretches. Willy stares at the Jesus statue, searching for feeling again, for hope. He crosses himself and mentally pleads t Jesus. Sayra turns and sees him praying.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: What are you asking him for?  74 75 71.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Too much.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: I prayed for us both. Willy is touched by Sayra’s thoughtfulness and sincerity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air is cool and gray. A mist envelops the train track Out of the gray milkiness, shadowy figures emerge running along the tracks. They startle Willy. He readies himself for a possible Mara attack. His machete, at arms length, still his only accessory. Suddenly a sack of tortillas lands on his lap. He looks a oddly. Sayra stands and looks out. There are TWO DOZEN KIDS and ADULTS, peasants in simple clothes, throwing food to the IMMIGRANTS on the train. TWO nine years-old GIRLS run along Sayra and Willy’s car. Their smiles beam as they throw another bag that Sayra gr awkwardly. Inside are oranges.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: GIRLS
dialogues.text: (in unison) You’re welcome! Sayra and Willy smile at each other. Life is getting bett The train awakens as IMMIGRANTS scramble to catch the gif while yelling “thank you” and “God bless you” to the peasants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train cars SLAM into each other as the train slows to enter the Orizaba train yards. Willy and Sayra’s car is just about to cross a bridge spanning a deep gorge like river that divides the town an the industrial factories preceding the station.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We're going to have to jump down.

dialogues.speaker: HORACIO
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: The train station is gated, sometimes there are migra and judicial police.

dialogues.speaker: ORLANDO
dialogues.text: Where can we go then?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Around, as fast as we can. They gather their belongings. Horacio feels suddenly and begrudgingly dependent on Willy’s knowledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Maras’ Carrola comes to a skidding stop. Smiley jumps with the others and runs down the side of the train. The pitched POP of the hydraulic breaks scares him -- he jump back. The train pulls itself into the gated yard. He scans the train cars, all empty

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: Smiley, we’ll go around and follow the stragglers. (to his THREE others) Meet us on the other side of the station. They JUMP ONTO THE MOVING TRAIN, Scarface quickly jumping the other side of the train. Smiley hesitantly skitters across the coupler and jumps off on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sayra, Willy, Horacio, Orlando, and SEVEN other immigrant run down the streets, they are all out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scarface and Smiley turn down the street. EIGHT YOUNG MEN look at them curiously. One throws up his hand, stacking letters like sign-language. Suddenly they realize that th are in a Barrio 18 neighborhood. They’ve walked into the hornets next. They start to back peddle, but the BARRIO 18 members get YELLING after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sayra, Willy, Horacio, and Orlando on their last legs, meander down the crooked streets of Orizaba with a SEVEN other immigrants in tow. DONALD, who they haven't seen since Tierra Blanca appears next to them from a diagonal street. He starts running wi them.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Nice day for a run, eh? Sayra and Willy are not laughing. They jump down onto a dirt path that skirts a canal runni along the edge of the fenced train yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sayra, Willy, Horacio, Orlando, and Donald emerge from th canal on to the other side of the train yard, an open exp that faces the high mountains of Orizaba pass. From what they can see, there are TWENTY Immigrants casua waiting for the train to come through and no sign of poli or migra. They sit and catch their breath. Just then, ruckus erupts down towards the gate where the trains exit. THREE Maras, El Pajaro, El Sipe and El Chino rush out of Scarface’s Carrola. They scan the immigrants, trudging through huddled groups, throwing backpacks around and pus people. It is abundantly clear they are looking for Willy and making a huge, fearless stir.  79 74. Willy stands, calculates, has no options but to escape. H picks up his machete, walks back slowly, then crouches do ditch away from the station, making his way down the trac The Maras pass Sayra, Horacio, and Orlando. The family tr not to look in the direction where Willy went. El Sipe pauses, looking at Sayra suspiciously. He continu on. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy hides behind a boxcar, breathing hard, his heart thumping. El Chino is the first one to enter his alley of abandoned cars. He turns the corner where Willy is standi but he’s gone. El Chino keeps moving. Above, on top of the car, Willy lays on his belly. He loo around, El Pajaro approaches from the other side. Noticin El Sipe ahead of him, he climbs into the box car and look around. Willy can see him through holes in the roof, El S crosses the car onto the next tracks. Willy crawls down into the boxcar through a hole. He land nimbly, then carefully peaks down the line of cars to see Sipe and El Pajaro’s progress. THUMP. He looks up. Some one is one the roof. He steps back against the wall of the car, light rays streaming do around him, then a shadow. He sees a GUN in the man’s han It's El Pajaro. Willy stops breathing, they are right next to each other. The wind blows trash inside the car. El Pajaro stops, loo down. He doesn’t seem to see Willy. He keeps moving. Willy exhales. He waits for a moment, then slowly exits t car, tracking back towards the station. He passes another open boxcar, on the other side, El Sipe stares at Willy. Recognition clicks. WHOOMP. A rock slams into the side of his head. El Sipe collapses. Willy is confused. Then Horacio appears a car length down holding another rock in his hands. Willy’s face reveals shock, then relief.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Take the gun.

dialogues.speaker: HORACIO
dialogues.text: I’ll have none of it. Horacio kicks it under the train.

dialogues.speaker: HORACIO
dialogues.text: Leave my family now. You brought this, there’ll only be more to come. Willy nods to himself. He knows it’s true.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Let me cross the mountains with you, I’ll be gone by tomorrow. I promise. GUN SHOTS erupt from far away, echoing over them like fir works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bullet ZIPS over Smiley and Scarface’s head. They are trapped behind a car. Shards of glass spray over them as bullets THUMP into the rocking car. The Barrio 18 soldiers have fanned out down the street, making their way towards them, firing POT SHOTS, advancin the open, then retreating as Scarface fires back. Smiley is frozen with fear.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: Pull out your fucking gun, Smiley. Smiley fumbles for the pistol in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: How many bullets do you have?

dialogues.speaker: SMILEY
dialogues.text: Just these. Scarface sneaks a peak at the Barrio 18’s progress.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, these guys can’t aim for shit... A bullet zips by his head-

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: -Except that one. El Scarface leans out and starts firing.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: Go, go, go! Smiley rushes to the next car in a hurried retreat. The bullets zip all around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: El Pajaro drives the Carrola, El Chino holds a dazed El S in the back. They see El Scarface and Smiley in an adrenaline drained run heading towards them.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: Where the fuck where you guys? You didn’t hear the shots?

dialogues.speaker: EL PAJARO
dialogues.text: We did, but we almost had him, El Casper.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: So? Because of El Casper you pussy’s left me and Smiley to fight on our own? Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: EL PAJARO
dialogues.text: He’s on the train again. To D.F.

dialogues.speaker: EL SCARFACE
dialogues.text: This kid, Smiley, had my back. You didn’t. Remember that. We’re going to D.F. I’m going to kill this fucker. Move! El Pajaro moves out of his way. Scarface jumps into the c

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 81
dialogues.text: EXT. NORTHERN HIGHLANDS OF ORIZABA — DAY 82 The train heads towards a steep slope leading to a mounta range.  83 84 85 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sayra, Horacio and Donald shutter in the frigid air. They are all tucked into the protected under-section of a GRAI CONTAINER CAR, but it is freezing anyway. Horacio unwraps a BUNDLE of dirty blankets and decomposin sweaters. They try their best to cover themselves. Willy and Orlando hang from the side of the train car, holding their arms out, waiting for long blades of grass dry branches they can break free. Willy snatches up a long stalked weed and tosses it to Sa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've piled up a mound of burnable items. They move closer as Orlando sparks his lighter. Finally he’s got it, and the small, damp pile of material begins to smoke. Orlando, Willy and Sayra fan it, blowing into it. It catc and they all moan with pleasure as the heat radiates from flames. Willy lights a cigarette off of a branch and inhales gratefully, then passes it along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fire is only a pile of burning embers. Horacio quietl stares at the photograph of his family. Sayra notices. Strangely, she finds that it hurts her. Willy climbs out tries to gather more branches, but the tracks are sparse. He quickly dips his head back in, WHOOMPH, darkness consu them, they are in a tunnel, in complete darkness. After a few seconds, they see the sky again, and for a moment, catch a glimpse at the magnificent view they have from the side of the mountain, thousands of feet below a beautiful canyon extends into the horizon. The train passes into another tunnel and darkness consume them again.  86 87 78. Others MOAN on the train, some yell just because they thi it will make them feel warmer. The sound crescendos. As the train hits light again, Willy and Sayra realize th they are pressed intimately close together. Her hand innocently placed on his for warmth. They look at each other, slightly embarrassed, but she doesn’t let go of his hand. Horacio doesn’t seem to notic his attention and his mind somewhere off in New Jersey. They enter another tunnel and are consumed in darkness ag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has yet to peak over the highlands. The entire gr lays awkwardly upon one another. Frost covers their plast bags and the rails of the tanker. Willy and Sayra are still pressed together. All sleep. To the right, the Aztec pyramids of Teotihuacan rise from purple horizon, and to the left, the mass of Mexico City lurks ominously in a brown smoggy haze. The train cruises slowly through an insignificant looking town. Willy rises. No one notices him. He is tired, he ha slept awkwardly, and he is dazed. He hangs off the side of the car, he takes one last look sleeping Sayra, then hops swiftly to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy heads down a side street away from the train just a the last car passes by. The sudden silence is peaceful. He senses someone walking behind him. He turns, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Sayra? What the fuck have you done? She’s 50 feet behind him, approaching quickly.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: You were just going to leave?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: What have you done, Sayra?  88 89 79.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: I’m going with you. Willy sits down, visibly distraught.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Oh god... Oh god, oh god, oh god. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can’t take care of you.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: I didn’t ask you to.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Jesus, Sayra. Don’t you get it? I’m a dead man.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: I can help you.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You have no idea what you've done. He drops his head into his hands.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: On the train, 200 hundred immigrants stretch, wary, stres and paranoid, work out the kinks in their body from the l hours on the train; ready to scatter if LA MIGRA has set immigration checkpoint/raid for them in the train yards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horacio and Orlando stand next to the passing train, scan the passengers. Stress covers Orlando’s face.

dialogues.speaker: ORLANDO
dialogues.text: Maybe she went down to take a pee and the train left her? Horacio puts his hand on his shoulders, dipping his head.

dialogues.speaker: HORACIO
dialogues.text: She’s gone. Saying it, he realizes how sick this makes him feel. Dona stands behind them, staring sympathetically at Horacio.  90 80.

dialogues.speaker: ORLANDO
dialogues.text: So we wait here, we’ll wait for her to catch the next train.

dialogues.speaker: HORACIO
dialogues.text: We can’t wait for her.

dialogues.speaker: ORLANDO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HORACIO
dialogues.text: We keep going, or we won’t make it either. Orlando is devastated. Horacio comforts him... and himsel

dialogues.speaker: HORACIO
dialogues.text: There’s nothing we can do. She’s on her own path now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy and Sayra sit in a room filled with electronic merchandise, mismatching furniture, and tacky paintings. TIA TONA, a middle-aged woman with a large trunk-like bod and a pock-marked face paces the room while tutt-tutting Willy. Her presence is at once tough and mothering.

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: Aye Casper... why did you come here? You've put me in a tough position. Willy nods. Sayra seems to be in a trance, at once optimistic and absolutely petrified.

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: I think I can do what you ask of me, but it will not be easy, and I will need you to do a favor in return... for the risks involved for having seen you.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Whatever it takes, Tia.

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: Give me a day to arrange this. Are you two hungry? They both nod. Tia Tofa calls into another room...  91

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: Socuro! Chilaquiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy and Sayra stuff their mouths with chilaquiles. Tofia sips a beer while watching them.

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: You can sleep on the couch. (to Sayra) Do you want to clean up? Sayra nods.

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: You're a tiny little thing, but

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: think I have some stuff for you to change in to. Tia Tofia leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: I thought you said you didn’t have any family?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I don’t. She’s Vatos Locos. I used to do side jobs for her on this route.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: She can get us to the border? Willy nods.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: And you're coming with me? 81. 91 Tia Tia Tofia comes back in, dropping a sack of clothes in fr of Sayra.

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: Try these on. The shower is through there. Stay away from the windows, I don’t want anyone knowing you two are here. Sayra takes the clothes and disappears in the bathroom. T Tofia looks at Willy, gravely.  82.

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: What are you doing with that poor girl?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Nothing. Tia Tofa looks at him from the corner of her eye.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I’m going to help her find her family. That’s it.

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: Then what’1ll you do?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Disappear.

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: And what's in it for you?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Nothing. Tia Tofa laughs. Maybe she believes him. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: The border? You know what’s waiting for you there? Willy ignores her.

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: They called.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: What’d you tell them?

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: I ain’t seen you. Which was the truth, until now.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You won’t tell them now, will you?

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: I always do what’s right. They both share a tense laugh.

dialogues.speaker: 91B
dialogues.text: 92 93 83. EXT. MARA HOUSE, D.F. — DAY 91A Smiley sits on the back patio, a cigarette in his hand. H head is on the lap of a CUTE GIRL while El Happy, a local Marero, uses a homemade tattoo gun to scrawl “M S 13” on inside of his lip. El Scarface sits approvingly nearbye. It’s painful, so Smiley closes his eyes. When he opens th again, El Sol, El Bomba, El Smokey, and El Pigaro are standing over him. EXT. PLACE HOLDER - TIA TONA’S HOUSE - DAY 91B Sayra and Willy have some moments of relaxation, happines optimism. Picking fruit. Playing with a kid or feeding animals. Putting on fresh clothes. Just being kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy and Sayra sit in the back of a beat up Van filled w MICHELADA MIX boxes. Tia Tofia sits in the passenger seat YOUNG BOY is driving, he doesn’t even look old enough to a license.

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: The madrina will get you as far as Monterrey. From there you’1ll make the delivery where Tia Estela will arrange for a car to take you to Reynosa. We notice Willy holding a paper bag between his legs. He stuffs it into a backpack.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: On the rolling hills north of Mexico City, Horacio and Orlando’s red freight train speeds around reservoirs and quaint villages. It moves faster than the other trains and they have to br themselves for the turns and bumps that are more shocking than the previous trains were.  94 84. There are few immigrants on this train. Perhaps no more t 100 for a train bigger than the one they began on in Chia The train passes through a neighborhood where the childre are walking to class in their school uniforms. As soon as they see the train, the kids begin to yell. At first Orlando think it’s cute, all of the kids running along with them. But then the kids start picking up rocks and throwing them. The large rocks bounce hard off the fa moving train. He is shocked. The CHILDREN laugh as they throw the rocks yell at the immigrants on the train. ADULTS watch from the doorsteps of dilapidated concrete houses, but they do nothing to stop the kids. One rock bounces off an immigrant’s head and lands next t Horacio. The immigrant grasps his head in pain. The duck cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tia Tofia’s Van drives them down an industrial road. A concrete tower looming over them is marked with an “MS” a the Devil’s Hand. Below is written: “Lil' Mago, El Casper no pasaraé!" He notices but does not point it out to Sayra. At the end the block Willy notices a medium sized CAR TRAILER loaded with THREE crashed cars.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Thank you Tia.

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: Don’t thank me, just make the delivery. Tia Tofa hands him a plastic bag of snacks for the journe Willy and Sayra slip out of the car and skitter towards t madrina. Tia Tofia looks at the caller ID of her ringing phone. She picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy and Sayra climb up the madrina. Willy opens the doo and motions for Sayra to get in, she’s about to when she pauses...

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Why do you get to drive?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Because Nena, this is my ranfla. She rolls her eyes and gets in. He gets in after and sett in.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You really want to sit here? (he gestures to move) Wait? Do you have a license Miss?

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Ah, well, then you can’t. He sits back down, then notices her mood has shifted. She feels an undesirable sense of loneliness setting in and t to play it off.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Scared?

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: No. Why? I’m with you, I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You're not fine because you're with me.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: I don’t care... I trust you. She touches his cheek. He leans away.  86.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Why? I don’t even trust me. He lifts up his pant leg. A scar crosses his calf.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You see this scar here, a police officer in Tamaulipas shot me when I was leading a group of pollitos to the border, for my clica. He lifts up his shirt, showing another keloid scar on his cage.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is where I took a bullet from a diecioyo, for my clica. He points at more scars across his body.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And here, and here, and here, all for my clica -- my family. Willy points at his cheekbone.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got this the night my “homies,” who I’d been defending with my life, killed the girl I loved. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I couldn't do nothing for her. That’s “trust,” Sayra.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: We both know loss.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: What I know... I know I fucked up my life already, I fucked her life... and now maybe... maybe I fucked up your life, too.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: You didn’t fuck it up. You saved me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sayra sleeps hard against the window. Willy watches her breath fog up the window around her mouth rhythmically.  97 98 87. He pulls out his camera and turns on the playback. He loo at an IMAGE that he took of he and Martha Marlene togethe His TEAR tattoo looks striking in the photo. He turns off the camera. Sadness leads to anger. He adjusts the rearview mirror so that he can look at himself. He feels the tear drop tattoo next to his eye an starts to rub it hard. Then he begins to scratch at it, until it bleeds, but he doesn’t stop, he keeps scratching Sayra winks one eye open, notices what he’s doing but doe say anything, pretending to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck speeds through a desert highland with sharp bed mountains rising high into the sky like piled tombstones stacked one against another. The towns are as sandy and brown as the landscape. There few signs of the lush greenery they saw in the south.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the sun rises, Willy still sleeps. Sayra notices the s illuminating the northern plains. In the distance, Sayra see the purple haze of the metropolis of Monterrey approaching.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Willy? Willy turns away, trying to keep sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (nudging his shoulder) Willy? Willy doesn’t wake up. Sayra looks in the mirror at herse She’s still pretty, but her beauty is hidden by fatigue, dirt, and scraggly hair. She smells and notices the air is slightly foul. She smel her clothes, sucking in hard with her nose, then she lean over and breaths in Willy. She scrunches her nose; he stinks, too. He opens his eyes when her face is next to his, but they only look at each other, Willy does nothing. She pulls away slowly.  99 100 101 102

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: The truck passes a MILITARY checkpoint. Willy and Sayra watch them from above. The truck is waved through and ent the urban center of Monterrey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The madrina pulls into a demolition center. El Sol, Scarface, Smiley and dozens of others from the gang wait hiding. Smiley looks nervous and scared. With guns out and ready, they quickly open all the cars. Smiley doesn’t look. When he turns back around, he sees t disappointment on El Sol and El Scarface’s faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy leads Sayra into an abandoned cinema palace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy leads her up a decaying side concrete staircase to room covered in a layer of greasy dust. A a single seat a rotten mattress adorn the space.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Wait here.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: I’m going to get us water. You should rest, you look like shit. He smiles and pats her leg, leaving his BACKPACK with her  103 104 105 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy walks down a crowded street. The faces, both indifferent and malevolent streak past. Willy begins to f paranoid, the panic becomes so heavy that he forces himse against a wall to breathe. He spots a telephone. He goes it. Dials. Listens.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Tia.

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: (surprised) Willy? So nice to hear from you.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Surprised?

dialogues.speaker: TIA TONA
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sayra, bored, begins to explore the building. It’s like something out of the apocalypse. Blown out windows, crumbling floors and ceilings, grandiose stairways and terraces. She walks up an opulent set of stairs to the 2nd floor an into the theatre’s main room. It’s an immense space, probably able to fit thousands at one point. At the front of the balcony, she sees that many have stay this place. Hundreds of names are scribbled around. One marking: “Oriana Carbajal-Hernandez, septiembre 2001. Sayra takes a piece of concrete and scratches in her own name: “Sayra Miranda Guzman.” She stares at her second to last name, “Miranda.” She sits in one of the seats and opens up the backpack. Afraid to open the package that Tia Tofa gave him, she lo at Willy's camera. She turns it on and flips through the pictures, the sound of Martha Marlen’s voice fills her wi rising sense of jealousy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE VEHICLES, El Scarface’s crew, El Sol’s Crew and a n clica’s car, an early-Eighties LINCOLN cruises down a highway, past a sign posting: REYNOSA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stereo system BLASTS beats from a REGGAETONE song. A D.F. RANFLERO, 30, drives with El Sol in the front. Smiley sits in the back with El Bomba and El Piqaro who t on his cell phone. Smiley notices that this ranfla (car*) has a lot more leg room than previous cars.

dialogues.speaker: SMILEY
dialogues.text: I like your ranfla. The Ranflero looks at Smiley like he’s talking shit.

dialogues.speaker: SMILEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, I’m serious, it’s got leg room. El Sol get’s off his phone.

dialogues.speaker: EL SOL
dialogues.text: What do you need legroom for? You're feet don’t even reach the floor. Smiley bristles.

dialogues.speaker: EL BOMBA
dialogues.text: What are you going to do when you find El Casper, Smiley? Hug him?

dialogues.speaker: SMILEY
dialogues.text: Shut up- El Bomba slaps him on the back of the head.

dialogues.speaker: EL BOMBA
dialogues.text: Now what are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: EL PIQARO
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Casper would fuck Smiley up. The Mareros can’t stop laughing. Smiley is silently simmering with anger.  108 109 gl.

dialogues.speaker: EL SOL
dialogues.text: Any of you kill Casper before Smiley and he’ll never be able to go home.

dialogues.speaker: RANFLERO
dialogues.text: (dead pan) The kid doesn’t have it in him. Why don’t you just kill him? El Bomba and Pigaro bust up laughing.

dialogues.speaker: EL BOMBA AND EL PIQARO
dialogues.text: Whoa! Smiley is on the verge of crying, inside he fumes.

dialogues.speaker: EL SOL
dialogues.text: We don’t kill little girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy waits near the telephone booth. An older model Mercedes pulls up and he gets in. The car pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIA ESTELA, a well dressed woman, slender and in her fift sits in the back seat with him. The driver, HERNAN is a heavy set man of her same age.

dialogues.speaker: TIA ESTELA
dialogues.text: Tofia told me you need a ride. Willy nods. She gestures to the driver.

dialogues.speaker: TIA ESTELA
dialogues.text: You have a package for me?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: No. Not until I get to where I need to go. Tia Estela nods, knowing the game.

dialogues.speaker: TIA ESTELA
dialogues.text: Hernén will take you. You had one more with you, no?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We'll pick her up.

dialogues.speaker: TIA ESTELA
dialogues.text: As you wish. Hernan. Hernén pulls the car over. Tia Estela gracefully exits, t looks seductively at Willy.

dialogues.speaker: TIA ESTELA
dialogues.text: You’1l let me know won’t you?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: About the package?

dialogues.speaker: TIA ESTELA
dialogues.text: If you travel alone next time. She winks at him, closes the door and leaves. Willy slide down into the leather seats and air conditioning, amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the digitally recorded sound of Martha Marlen and Willy echoing over the expanse of the theatre. As we hear the conversation, we see more details of the decaying spa and evidence of the past immigrants who have gone through

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA MARLEN DIGITAL
dialogues.text: Come on... Tell me...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY DIGITAL
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA MARLEN DIGITAL
dialogues.text: Say it better.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY DIGITAL
dialogues.text: I love you so much I don’t know better words to describe it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA MARLEN DIGITAL
dialogues.text: If you had to measure it with your hands.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY DIGITAL
dialogues.text: I couldn't, I couldn’t even with miles, you’d like, you’d like need light years to measure it. She giggles. We see Sayra staring at the video. It’s the last night Martha Marlen and Willy were together.  93.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA MARLEN DIGITAL
dialogues.text: Take me with you to the cemetery tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY DIGITAL
dialogues.text: No... I’1l see you after.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA MARLEN DIGITAL
dialogues.text: Come on, why?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY DIGITAL
dialogues.text: You wouldn't like it anyway. Come here, turn that off... let me kiss you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA MARLEN DIGITAL
dialogues.text: Say it...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY DIGITAL
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horacio, Orlando, and Donald sit atop a moving train, exi the station. An overpass crosses the train yard in front them, providing a welcome bit of shade from the sun. PLACE HOLDER -- ORLANDO CONFRONTS HORACIO ABOUT SAYRA. Orlando takes a sip of dirty water from his bottle, using shirt as a filter.

dialogues.speaker: ORLANDO
dialogues.text: I keep thinking I see Sayra... everywhere. Horacio let’s his thoughts drift to his daughter again. Sadness covers his face. Orlando and Donald's eyes have d dark rings and their foreheads are burnt.

dialogues.speaker: HORACIO
dialogues.text: All we can hope is that she is okay. Orlando can only blink. They look miserable.

dialogues.speaker: MIGRA OFFICER 1, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Down, pigs! Horacio looks down to see FOUR MIGRA OFFICERS in the back a PICK UP TRUCK paralleling them, their rifles are out an they are waiving them down.  112 113 94. Horacio, Donald and Orlando jump up and run towards the b The truck slows down to match their position. They pause, Orlando doubles over. Donald finds a hiding s BETWEEN TWO CARS. Horacio starts to run in the opposite direction. Orlando to make a huge effort to keep up, leaping from train car train car. The train picks up more speed, Horacio and Orlando brace themselves as the cars YANK each other. Horacio jumps to next car. Orlando stops, then starts again because he thought he di have the speed. When he looks up, Horacio is not there. He runs to the edge of the car, but Horacio isn’t there either. The Migra Truck is catching up. He scrambles down the oth side of the train and dashes away.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: Just before sunrise, the Mercedes zooms past the shotgun pierced sign “REYNOSA.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy and Sayra exit the car, stretch, and look around. T square is deserted. Willy leans down and thanks the driver, then waits for th car to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sayra knocks on the door of the shelter. A priest, PADRE MIGUEL, late-forties, wearing casual clothes and plastic slippers, opens the door and beckons in the entire group.

dialogues.speaker: PADRE MIGUEL
dialogues.text: Good morning. Come in.  114

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit around a covered veranda. Another group of immigrants wait to be helped, a skinny m who we'll call BIG LIPS stares hard at Willy. Willy notic and averts his eyes. The SISTER enters the veranda and begins passing out the cards.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: This card is your ticket. It’s valid for three nights, after that you have to leave to make room for the new people. You will get two meals a day, lunch and dinner. Please respect the rules written on the wall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy showers. He takes stock of himself in front of the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy, almost dried off, puts on a clean shirt. He gets u to look for Sayra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy walks down the hallway calling for Sayra, anger ris Big Lips, and several other immigrants block his way.

dialogues.speaker: BIG LIPS
dialogues.text: We don’t want your kind here.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You make the rules?

dialogues.speaker: BIG LIPS
dialogues.text: You're a Marero.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Not anymore. Big Lip shoves his finger in Willy's face.

dialogues.speaker: BIG LIPS
dialogues.text: We don’t want you here. Immigrants turn their attention to the fuss growing betwe Big Lips and Willy. Suddenly we see that DONALD is one of them. Willy grabs Big Lips pointed finger and yanks it down, quickly grabbing his neck and shoving Big Lips face to th concrete floor. All the anger he had building up he takes out on Big Lips. The blood in his veins of his forehead p Sayra comes out, shocked to see Willy on top of the man. Donald enters the fray, separating the two men. Willy looks around, everyone is staring at him tensely. H lets go of Big Lips, who jumps back and wipes his face of

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Calm down, son. Donald guides Sayra and Willy back towards the dorm room. The Sister walks in.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: What’s going on in here?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Nothing, Mother. Big Lips and the other immigrants say nothing. INT. SHELTER DORM ROOM - CONTINUOUS 115¢ Willy, Sayra, and Donald sit together. Willy puts on a wi beater that shows less of his tattoos. Donald is quiet. H isn’t his previous jovial self.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Hey... She is happy to see him and avoid what ever anger Willy h

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you're here, too. Have you seen my father and uncle? He nods, gravely. Sayra can tell he has something to say.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: What?  97.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: I have bad news. Your Uncle has been deported, and your father is with the angels. Sayra doesn’t believe it, nor can Willy. She’s in complet denial, until Donald grabs her hands. At first she laughs like she thinks it’s a joke. Willy doesn’t know what to d He tries to reach out to touch her, but hesitates. Sayra, unexpectedly even to herself, cries. She stands an leaves the room, leaving Willy and Donald sitting with ea other.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Migra came, they tried to run, he fell under the train. They sit in silence. Willy nods to himself, trying to mentally reorganize his thoughts and plans. He massages t tattoos on his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sayra cries by herself on a pew. Willy enters and sits do next to her silently. She leans on him and cries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The streets are busy with cars, music, and day trippers. Willy and Sayra walk near a bridge that crosses into the Willy notices a CARLOAD OF MAREROS posted in front of it. Along the water, Mareros casually hang out where immigran gather to cross over illegally. They keep walking up river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mexican side of the river is a maze of thick, high we that resemble a super sized briar patch. Willy and Sayra maneuver their way through the weeds until it opens up al the creamy-green Rio Bravo. It’s an encampment of immigrants, covered in the refuse o the hundreds who have passed through it before.  120 98. SEVERAL men rest under a tree. There are NEEDLES on the ground near them.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We're looking for a pato. One of the men, LECHE, late-twenties, skinny and pale lik junkie looks up at them. He wears a baseball cap and a bl shirt with a giant SNOW TIGER face.

dialogues.speaker: LECHE
dialogues.text: You want to cross?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Garage mainly used for tires is situated a stones throw from the river. SEVERAL shady looking characters lounge in front of it. E Sol, Scarface, and Smiley walk towards it. One of the workers, with a forehead so big it’s a FIVE HE late-teens, sits up. Leche has arrived, cash in hand. He holds up his fingers like the “peace” sign.

dialogues.speaker: LECHE
dialogues.text: Two. And if you could fill them for me, these two want to go right away.

dialogues.speaker: FIVE HEAD
dialogues.text: I’ve only got one now. Leche nods “okay.”

dialogues.speaker: FIVE HEAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Won't be able to cross ‘til the Border Patrol change at four thirty anyway.

dialogues.speaker: LECHE
dialogues.text: Don’t matter, I get paid either way. The Mareros are intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy and Sayra sit on the waters edge. They look at the spinning signs of fast food restaurants the U.S. side of the river.  99.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: We can go anywhere now.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We'll go to New Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter to me. Willy smiles wistfully. She leans on him.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not allowed to hug you? Willy shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: When we get to the other side, I want you to make me a promise.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: No matter what happens, you’ll try to find your family.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: They're not my family.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You've got little sisters who don’t have a father now.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: I'd just be a burden, like I am to everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: To me no. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you could help them. You could work or something.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: You'd be with me?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Of course. She shyly hands him the camera. He’s surprised. He looks her, only slightly angered, but more happy to have the ca back.  121 122 100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leche leads Willy and Sayra through the maze of weeds. A SILHOUETTE dashes across an opening in the distance. No o notices it but Willy. He grabs onto Sayra and pushes her along faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leche sits on an INNER-TUBE in a speedo.

dialogues.speaker: LECHE
dialogues.text: I can only take one of you at a time.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: We paid for two tubes. Leche shrugs. He’s not changing his mind. Sayra notices that Willy is heavily disappointed about this. He motions for her to go.

dialogues.speaker: LECHE
dialogues.text: Money?

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Once we get across. Leche clicks his tongue, no. He holds out his hand. Neith Willy nor Sayra have any money. He reaches into his pocke and gives Leche the camera. Leche inspects it. Accepts. Sayra is bitter-sweetly amazed.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You first. Sayra looks at him nervously.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go on, now. She hugs him tightly, he kisses her on her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Leche) Hey, you. Turn around. Willy points at Leche, who was watching Sayra optimistica Willy gives Sayra her privacy too and turns around, just he sees movement again in the tall weeds.  101.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hurry up and get in the water, girl. Sayra undresses to her underwear quickly, puts her clothe a plastic bag and slips into the water. Willy turns aroun he tells Sayra slowly and deliberately...

dialogues.speaker: WILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It‘’ll be okay. Leche grabs onto a rope tied to the BLACK INNER-TUBE and pulls Sayra into the current of the river. Sayra watches Willy as she’s pulled further into the rive there is a sadness in his eyes. She suddenly understands why, he’s not getting ready. A TATTOOED FACE appears in a clearing. She barely has tim to warn him when he raises a chimba, BAM! A bullet whizze over Willy’s head. Willy ducks, then picks up a rock and throws it at the Marero. Willy darts into the briar patch of tunnels. Sayra yells after him...

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Willy! But he’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Leche) We have to go back.

dialogues.speaker: LECHE
dialogues.text: No. She struggles with Leche.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Let go of me, let go.

dialogues.speaker: LECHE
dialogues.text: If you get off you’1ll drown. There are whirlpools all along that bank.  123 124 102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rustling footsteps increase, silhouettes and shadows by Willy. COOING and CAWING sounds from all directions. T turns and roundabouts in the maze become blurs. Willy comes face to face with another MARERO, his entire is covered in tattoos. Willy ducks as he lunges for him. He dives behind a log. His fingers scan the ground for a weapon, he finds a boulder and waits. As another set of footsteps approach, he jumps out, hamme the bolder into a man’s stomach. He looks down, it’s El S gasping for air. Willy dashes for the river, but just when he gets to the edge, he sees Smiley blocking his way, the rusted revolve hanging heavily in his lowered hand.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Smiley? Smiley looks up at Willy fearfully, his mouth goes dry. Willy implores him with his eyes to let him by. The silhouettes of the pursuing Maras, including El Scarf fast approach. Smiley can see them, feel the pressure of getting closer, his eyes change to confused, sad anger. H raises the pistol.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Smiley...

dialogues.speaker: SMILEY
dialogues.text: La Mara, carnal. BAM! Smiley fires into Willy’s stomach. It leaks blood. Willy stumbles to the waters edge. Crying, he fires again. WHAM! The bullet hits his kidney. Then again and again and again.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER SIDE OF THE RIVER 124
dialogues.text: Sayra just reaches the shore as the second shot blasts ou She screams...  125 126 127 128 129 103.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Willy! (to Leche) We have to go back for him. Leche backs into the weeds on the U.S. side of the river, then turns and runs away. She grabs the inner-tube and jumps back into the water. She struggles to swim back towards Willy but the current already brought her far enough down river that it’s makin impossible for her to get back to his position. EXT. WILLY AND SMILEY’S SIDE OF THE RIVER 125 More Mareros gather, watching Willy stumble into the wate Suddenly they open up on him, BULLETS from their wide var of weaponry pummeling his body. The Mareros each take turns spitting on him. Smiley is th only one not to do it. He looks at Willy’s body with a mixture of hurt and nausea. SIRENS from both sides of the river approach their direct As a group the men disappear into the shadows of the weed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sayra cannot compete with the force of the current, she’s floating away. She stops trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO U.S. Border Patrol vehicles speed to the site, drawn the gun fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mareros follow Willy's body as it drifts down stream, silently observing its progress from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWATER 129
dialogues.text: Willy's lifeless body leaks black blood into the green wa  130 131 132 133 134 104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Border Patrol vehicles follow as well. Sayra ditches the inner-tube and struggles to an alcove o weeds on the U.S. side of the river. She collapses with fatigue and cries. She breathes hard a the weight of all that has happened sinks in. Her labored breathing slowly becomes a heavy, moaning cry. She has lo everyone.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: INT. EL LIL' MAGO’S HOUSE, TAPACHULA - DAY MUSIC fades in. The LOCATION SOUND is practically muted a the music ties one character to the next... Smiley sits in the middle of the destroyer. Other Maras mingle around him, but he doesn’t look at them. He stares past us absently, as if he were looking at something 1000 yards away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orlando, on the same river we began the film, steps onto raft with a small group of immigrants. His face shows the fatigue from the journey, but there is nothing in his face that shows he’s going to give up. Around him, other immigrants, individuals and families, m their first steps on a journey he knows all too well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sayra finishes dressing herself. She washes her hands and face in the river, then disappears into the shrubs toward the U.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy’s lifeless face peeks from a closing PINE BOX COFFI A WORKER staple guns the lid shut. 130 131 132 133 134  135 136 137 105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same pine box is slid into a grave, then filled with by a tractor. A wooden cross reads: “Sin Nombre” and is surrounded by hundreds of similar wooden crosses marked w the same “Sin Nombre.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sayra walks in a sort of trance through a field of tall, green grass and flowers. Her face is both tired and peaceful. As Willy described it, there is something beautiful about Texan landscape, like a painting, especially in the early light. EXT. MCALLEN, TEXAS —- DAY 137 Sayra walks across a wide boulevard into the gigantic par lot of a super mall. She sees a pay phone on the sidewalk. She stares at it. S decides to go to it. She picks up the receiver, reads the info on the phone, written in Spanish, on how to make COLLECT CALLS. She dia the number she was forced to memorize.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: (whispering to herself) 9-0-8-555-0-1-8-7 The muffled voice of an OPERATOR echoes through the line. Sayra is confused, she answers in english “yes” with out knowing what she is answering to. The phone begins to ring. And ring. And ring. The VOICE o Yessenia picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SAYRA
dialogues.text: Yessenia? This is... Sayra. As we pull high and away, we loose her in the colorful mo of hundreds of cars.
